awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Models, Algorithms, and Simulations for Two-Phase Ferrofluid Flows in Contact with a Solid Surface
awd_abstract_narration:
Being controllable by applied magnetic fields, two-phase ferrofluid flows have found diverse applications in various science and engineering fields. Flows of two-phase ferrofluid mixtures usually involve the coupling of hydrodynamics, interface motion, intrinsic particle spins, magnetization field, and induced magnetic field. It is expected that the proposed research will not only lead to reliable well-posed models, efficient numerical algorithms for the two-phase ferrofluid system, but also extend the applicability of mathematical models, analyses and codes to various physical problems of current interest through numerical simulations.  The proposed research will produce efficient, optimally convergent, easily implemented, energy stable numerical algorithms, as well as publicly available finite element codes. It will provide ample and valuable opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to receive multidisciplinary training in the areas of mathematical modeling, computational mathematics, and mechanical engineering, and to develop state-of-the-art mathematical models and numerical algorithms for science and engineering applications. Starting from this collaborative work, the investigators plan to disseminate the developed models, methods and software packages to more engineers and scientists for solving their realistic problems, present the research in professional conferences and colloquia, and organize special sessions/minisymposiums in domestic/international conferences for related works.


The intellectual merit of this project lies in the challenge to develop suitable mathematical models and design efficient and accurate schemes for the highly nonlinear two-phase ferrofluid system, which couples free interfaces, hydrodynamics, magnetization field, induced magnetic field, and intrinsic particle spins. Very few efforts have been made to address the induced modeling/numerical challenges of the two-phase ferrofluid system due to the complicated nonlinear couplings among these constituents. The proposed models are thermodynamically consistent and thus preserve the energy dissipation laws. With strengths of the finite element methods in dealing with the complex boundary, the proposed numerical schemes are efficient, accurate, easily implemented, and energy stable with some discrete energy dissipation laws which have advantages of allowing the large time step and controlled error bound to capture the interfacial singularities accurately. In addition, the models, numerical algorithms and simulations will contribute to better understandings of various physical problems of practical interests, such as new materials based on ferro fluids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ferrofluids (also called magnetic fluids) are colloidal solutions made of ferromagnetic nanoparticles suspended in a dispersing liquid (usually an organic solvent or water).  The interest in ferrofluids arises from a fact that it combines the hydrodynamic behavior of Newtonian liquids with the magnetic properties of super-paramagnets. Thus such a fluid can be controlled directly by the application of a magnetic field. Their basic properties, including the high magnetic polarization of saturation and zero remanence, predestine their applications in some systems that need precise control, such as optics, drug delivery, and electronic devices. Some emerging applications of ferrofluids can be found in nano-technologies and biomedical engineering, including assembly of micro/nano-particles, fluid transport and control, and the treatment of retinal detachment, etc.

 

The hydrodynamics of magnetic suspension, known as ferrohydrodynamics (FHD), was well established by two generally accepted constitutive models, the Rosensweig and Shliomis models, which both treat ferrofluids as homogeneous fluids. Although one might think that it would be natural to extend the existing works of Rosensweig or Shliomis constitutive models for monophase ferrofluid system to the two-phase scenario, the reality is quite the opposite, since the mechanisms that select interfacial singularities and deformation dynamics vary with the magnetization properties of the two types of fluids and their mutual interactions. The rheology of two-phase ferrofluid system can become highly complex because it is an interactive system, in which the applied magnetic field tends to deform the interface, drive the flow direction inside the bulk or near the contact lines whereas interfacial changes affect the hydrodynamics, magnetization and intrinsic spins of particles in turn.

 

Even though the two-phase free flow system has been studied by the methods mentioned above theoretically and numerically, the mathematical studies (modeling, algorithms, and analysis) for two-phase ferrofluid system remain a rich research area with important topics that can be addressed. Major challenges include but not limited to (i) the topology of the interface can change drastically (breakup or self-assembly), for which, the traditional sharp interface model usually leads to an almost intractable theoretical problem; (ii) open issues regarding the model wellposedness which leads to confusion about whether numerical pathologies arise from the model or numerical methods; and most importantly; (iii) the nonlinear couplings among a quantity of physical variables (hydrodynamics, interface, magnetic induction field, magnetizations and angular momentum), together with the complicated MCL boundary conditions make it significantly difficult to design reliable (stable and accurate) numerical schemes.

 

Therefore, in this project we:  (i) derive suitable energetic variational phase-field models for the two-phase ferrrofluid flow system that couples the hydrodynamics, magnetic field or magnetism, interfacial dynamics and moving contact lines; (ii) develop efficient, easy-to-implement, energy stable numerical schemes to accurately capture the dynamics of interface singularities; and (iii) perform numerical simulations as well as lab experiments to validate the models and numerical schemes, and further study physically motivated problems.

 

At Missouri University of Science and Technology, three Ph.D. students in mathematics and two Ph.D. students in mechanical engineering were partially supported by this project. The funding enabled these graduate students to make great progress in research. Furthermore, the unique training and working experience in both mathematics and mechanical engineering helped the involved students well understand the dynamic interaction between what they learn in computational mathematics and what they need for realistic engineering problems, hence greatly benefit these future applied mathematicians and engineers, whose work will be tightly associated with realistic applications. One of the three Ph.D. students in mathematics and the two Ph.D. students in mechanical engineering have graduated.

 

Missouri Institute for Computational and Applied Mathematical Sciences is being expanded at Missouri University of Science and Technology.  Funding for this project promoted these initiatives and enhanced the relatively small amount of computational mathematics research in the state of Missouri.
